posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53111977
>meme types
>bug and ice
Ice just got another huge buff in gen 9 after a string of them for the past couple games. The defense boost in snow combined with aurora veil and the often high natural defenses of ice types makes them incredible physical walls, they can often even tank a hit or two from three of their weaknesses because special-type fighting rock and steel moves are all hard to come by. Even with all that it's not a fantastic type, but I really couldn't call it a meme anymore.
Bug catches shit for good reason, but I do think it's worth noting that having resists to both fighting and ground is great for it, since those are the tied best offensive types in the game (or at least, they both hit 5 other types SE). Really the only buff I'd give bug is making it resist fairy, otherwise the main thing holding back bug types is just the fact that most of them suck.
Oh, Stealth Rocks also hurts the hell out of these, but it's been getting easier to counter it for a while now. I still personally wish it never existed but here we are. The design purpose of SR is to make an entry hazard that can hit flying types and levitate, so I always thought it'd make more sense if they made electroweb an entry hazard, since it'd have much less collateral damage and act as a deserved nerf to water.

>what about grass
Resisting ground, electric, and water is fantastic. Being weak to bug and poison is less important than you think because both are decidedly bad offensive types so it's not too common to be threatened by those. Bug especially is rarely available for non-bug pokemon. Being weak to ice is offset by the fact that only water and ice types tend to learn decent ice type moves. Water is weak to grass, so carrying ice beam only makes the matchup even(ish), while Ice is, even now, a type with many readily available counters that should be on your team.
Offensively, Grass is also one of Water's 2 (TWO?) weaknesses, making it okay coverage by default.

>>53113412
I've said it before and I will say it again. If they swap the relationship between bug and fairy so that Bug is the one that resists Fairy and not the other way around, it would go a long way. Then they need to make Bug resist itself and cut back on the distribution of U-turn. I think those alone would help Bug types see more play. Bugs now don't have to worry about Fairies halting their attacks, and now Bug/Grass, -Psychic or -Dark types no longer have to worry about a Bug weakness. U-turn would be more special since only Bugs and some unique Pokemon or Flying types could have it. It's too ubiquitous now and mons like Annihilape like it but it's stupid they get to use it better than the Bugs themselves, so remove it. If they want to then go a step further they can make Bugs immune to forced switches because they're known for being "pesky." That way they can "stand their ground" and be immune to phazing or goofy shit like stall mons who force you back and forth with hazards out. Suddenly Pokemon like Forretress would have more usage and mons like Kleavor could safely set hazards and set up if the opponent doesn't react fast enough.

>>53113853
Ice was always a glass cannon type, that was always its deal. The problem was we never8 had enough Ice types who could actually take advantage of its high offensive pressure until very recently.
>Gen 1 gave us Articuno, Dewgong, Lapras, Cloyster and Jynx. Only Jynx actually had the Speed to really abuse it. The others were built to have high bulk, which didn't work so great after all the mechanical changes and power creep in later gens. Plus the best users of Ice moves were always Pokémon that weren't ice types, like all of the normal, psychic and water types running around.
>Later games kept adding Ice types with bad stats for actually sweeping or attacking, with few exceptions. And because Water types kept learning Ice Beam, the only benefit Ice had over alternatives was access to Ice Shard and abilities to abuse Hail.
>More recently they replaced Hail with Snow, we got Aurora Veil, and A-Ninetales became the new weather setter. We also Ice types who were specifically built to be sweepers and Tera. Ice is finally good. But all those old Ice types are still shit.

If you actually read the article, the main point they have is that Nidorans being treated as two separate pokemon doesn't make sense anymore when you have other pokemon that have distinct stats and appearances but are still considered the same species of pokemon with the same pokedex number (Indeedee) or that have different evolutions based on their gender. The Nidos being treated as two separate species in the game mechanics is a leftover from gen 1 when genders weren't an actual thing, and is probably the biggest reason we haven't seen them in more recent games since they're now an outlier with how pokemon genders work. They throw in some buffwords in, probably to get more clicks, but the point still stands.

Since GF has been limiting the ability to transfer pokemon from past games since gen 8 and no longer has the entire pokedex available in games even through transfer, they could just go and redesign the Nido line so that the male and female share a pokedex number, but it'd probably be too much work for a pokemon that isn't massively popular like Pikachu or gen 1 starters.

Yes, save after 60.
You usually eat the sandwich after you kill 60 unless you have troubles finding the mon, it depends on the outbreak.

Picnic reset is not always the best, there's a hard cap on how many pokemon can spawn around you, pokemon have specific spawns and if you sit still on the same spot you'll have to either wait until they move and more spawn or you'll get less spawns, personally I prefer moving around and respawning them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53107642
Outbreaks work on a per day basis and only on the outbreak itself.
So for example if you're doing a Flittle outbreak and you kill 60, it will boost the shiny odds for the flittle that spawn FROM the outbreak, not from the wild spawns.

Once the day rolls over, it will do new outbreaks, the game tries to give you an outbreak close to you and this is how you try to do specific outbreaks.

So your Flittle outbreak is gone and you'd have to do the battles again.
HOWEVER, you can just use the lets go auto battle thing, it can never kill a shiny and it will count on each kill, making it go by extremely fast

posts.com:
>>53112798
You're meant to kill 60, then save, close your game, fiddle with the clock until you get dusk/few minutes before THEN re-save and sandwich. If you don't get the dusk, restart, reset the clock to the time you'd just used to run the first hunt, then re-hunt, continually resetting the clock to allow Dusk spawns to happen.
You're right, trying this without thinking WILL be a pain in the arse. But that's why you think about it first.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53103298
You can usually add parenthesis around a term in your prompt to emphasize it, and brackets to decrease the importance of a term. So the previous “cute, grey cat” might look like “[cute],((grey cat)). Also, copy the exact tags as used on danbooru such as: may (pokemon). just look it up in the internet, there's plenty of good tutorials out there atm

>>53115808
I'm a graphic designer / artist / web developer who likes to be be creative during his free time, but I never really had the time or energy to really excel at drawing / game design or writing, though I had tons of passion and ideas. Last year Stable Diffusion released and I felt I had to stay up to date with the recent tech, since all these ai's can and will eventually influence my job. Instead of fighting it I feel like I should learn to use it to my advantage, since there's no way we're stopping it.

Apart from all that, it's fun. I can make my own reference material, try different styles, play with coloring or shading without having to spend hours upon hours of learning. Drawing a nice piece used to take weeks, and now I can combine the notorious 'soulless' ai art with my own skills and style and make something great, in a matter of hours. Back in the day you had to buy the newspaper in order to read the news, now you can take your phone out of your pocket, this is the same thing.

Oh, and also... infinite amount of great waifu art anon

>>53116747
because the vast majority of all human artists suck at hands. The ai does not think for itself, it's trained on their pics. It simply takes over their mistakes. It's also why the ai likes to get rid of hands in its pics (pic related), artists do that a lot. Hands, feet and eyes are the most common ai problems atm, since they're also the most common problems humans experience while drawing. This also means that if more people start to draw hands, feet and eyes to fix the ai's mistakes, in time the ai will become better at these things as well.

OP here, i use novelai, so all processing happens on their server. Any laptop / computer can do that. Its still possible if you want to run it locally, but your generations will take longer, ranging from a few seconds to a full minute. Its not very hard to learn if you keep experimenting. I'm not at home right now, otherwise I could show you my progress the past couple months, but I'll post it later today when I'm back. By now there's plenty of tutorials and guides. Novelai is easier since you have to tweak less stuff to make something nice, but yeah, its also a paid subscription.

Pretty straightforward, let us see if there’s a pattern to be found here… other than the fact they’re all starters.

>Charizard
Obligatory for KANTOOO
Has always been an honorary dragon-type.
>Cinderace
Included for the Year of the Rabbit.
Is an honorary fighting type.
>Greninja
Included because, uh, reasons.
Poison just to fuck up the type’s two counters.
>???

The obvious thing those three have in common is that they’re all the most popular starters of their respective generation. The Tera typing seems to depend on the shillmon’s honorary typing, or what it can fuck up the most.

If we go with Charizard’s and Cinderace’s case, Decidueye will receive a Flying Tera due to the fact it’s a bird. If we go with Greninja’s case, Delphox will definitely get a Fairy Tera just to fuck with the poison and steel types using its true typing.

posts.com:
>>53107953
Try to not just follow a pre-established build for a pokemon. Use them as a guide at best. Figure out what your pokemon needs to do in the team, then figure out what are the threats it will face (usage stats help here), then which of these threats you can deal with, which ones you can't, and build your pokemon from there.
Figure out speed first, who you want to outspeed/underspeed. Then move to defenses, which hits you want to live (prioritize hp over def/spdef). Then move to attack, how many evs you need to OHKO or 2HKO something this pokemon is meant to check/face.
Weight each stat differently, if you're playing Breeloom, Meowscarada, or Flutter Mane you don't really need to prioritize defense over offense. Finally, figure out some common flows. I.e., if you see a Murkrow (prankster tailwind) or Indeedee/Armarouge (trick room) what's the best Turn 1 your team can do against it?
This is the best way to actually know what your team can do, instead of running into a situation and having no clue what move to use, or if you survive.

posts.name: cge0361
posts.com:
>>53104595
>otherwise a skin flap that can peel down
The executive producer for Love Lost once drew a sketch page on that topic (don't ask, I got tired of carrying random image clutter years ago) but I've tried to avoid giving pokemon mammary glands. Miltank has a pass because the whole concept is that Pokemon tend to mimic the outward characteristics of animals and things but internally function quite differently. So a pokemon that mimics a dairy cow, which is selectively bred for lactation, sensibly mimics that capacity, but there's no real grounds for any other pokemon (that I know of) to offer dairy production.

>Whenever I see off model Gardevoir I always think of that
To be fair, I go off-model somewhat in my descriptions' details, because I prioritize motif and practicality over trying to bend over backwards to support the compromise that is cartoon art based off of what the sprite artists could pack into a Game Boy decades ago. Plus, there are greater narrative opportunities when you can have multiple levels of contrast. Allowing species with paws but anthropomorphic form (e.g., typhlosion or lucario) to be treated as not really having hands but being dexterous enough to get along in world built for fully functional thumbs opens the door for greater emphasis on pokemon who aren't given that conceit and must find other ways to struggle through, e.g. Idis, who has gotten a magnet embedded in her paw to be able to pick up things like pins and needles, which are very handy for picking locks and other things a naughty umbreon might want to do while not being suspected of being able to do them.

>remove the "blouse" and "gloves"
We can blame canon for this, for giving us a non-trivial number of pokemon with clothes-like…bodily components?…not really addressing them except for tongue-in-cheek hand-waves; like their reminding us that the spandex-and-belt appearance of machamp is not clothing and just what they look like, which only raises more questions.

I like Pokémon worldbuilding which accounts for the Pokémon as active participants in the world, not just tools for people.
For instance, one of the Pokemon settings I thought up has the franchises characteristic lack of explicit violence or dark themes being chalked up to a sort of Bene Gesserit order of gardevoirs/other select pokemon types, who have mentally/psychically manipulated mankind over the generations to be less unpleasant as a whole (All in the name of benefitting their trainers, of course). They've also used this to gain a position of power arguably equal to their supposed masters.
You see a ton of wars back in the lore of the games/anime, but nothing nearly so unpleasant in the current setting. Thought it'd be neat to explain that.

posts.com:
Hosting guide

1. open map in pokemon
2. press home button
3. go to settings, scroll all the way down
4. go to time, about 1/3 down
5. make sure synchronize is off, scroll down again to open date and time
6. click A (7) times
7. press home
8. open pokemon and find the poison glowing raid
9. post code

posts.name: Writefuck
posts.com:
Time for my threadly plug for the VN I'm writing. Hang out with Cynthia in Olivine City and solve crimes! Also featuring Jasmine. It's completely free.

writefuck.itch.io/olivinelights

>What's new?

Mostly finished writing a sidequest with Jasmine. It took a little while due to some writers' block, but it's in a good place. I've implemented some achievements (picrel) which primarily are there so the player/reader knows what content has and hasn't been seen yet. Achievements will be persistent between playthroughs and some of them also unlock things in an "extras" menu that will include things like showing your cynthia_love and jasmine_love stats, or starting off with your pokemon evolved. This will probably all be available in the next major update, but...

I'm having a hard time commissioning actual art for this for some reason. I need several SFW CG's and a whole bunch of NSFW ones, and I have plenty of money to throw at some artists, but out of everyone I PM'd or DM'd, almost no one has even answered me. Maybe I'm just being impatient, I dunno. I need a better way to recruit artists than just cold calling randos. I wish I had artist friends.

I'm getting increasingly uncomfortable with the fact that the VN contains art that's completely stolen from pixiv or deviantart and used without permission. My priority for commissioning CG's is to replace all the stolen art with paid art that I have permission to use. I might open up a ko-fi or something after I've done that. I won't put this behind a paywall, but I won't decline donations once I'm not using stolen art anymore. I'm not worried about official art or sprites stolen from Nintendo since I'm using their IP anyway, and I'm pretty sure I'm covered under fair use doctrine regardless. I just don't feel right stealing art from random strangers even though I'm not making money off of it. I might hold off on releasing another update until I have new art to replace the stolen assets. Not sure.

inb4 "just use AI"

Pao is absolutely broken, more than Chi-Yu ever was.
It outspeeds EVERYTHING except Dragapult which is weak to both its priority STABs for starters.
Tera Band Crunch 2HKOs at worst everything in the tier including resists, so absolutely nothing but certain scarfers, priority users or strategic Terastal mons can check it.
Tera Blast Electric beats all of its "checks" if you run HDB.
It's not that squishy either, 80/80 physical bulk is respectable.
Its defensive type is not that useless, it has key resistances that can be exploited.
Pao is a premier wallbreaker, revenge killer and sweeper all rolled into one. No other offensive mon in the tier can compress all offensive roles in a single set and excel at all of them at once.
Chi-Yu is a nuke, but 100 base speed means it either wallbreaks or runs scarf and Overheat can't be spammed as much as Pao's STABs, plus it has no priority.

posts.com:
Bored out of my mind and it wandred to comp, so I'm gonn type out some changes I'd make to the past 3 generational gimmicks if they're ever to return in an official capacity
>Megas
The stats gained now scale with the initial BST of the mon. For example, if a mon had less than, say, 500 BST, they'd get the full 100 BST boost, but if they had 600 BST, they'd get a heavily reduced BST bump of only around 10. This forces the already "strong" Pokemon getting Megas to take those optimal stats from an actual place they'd miss then rather than becoming nonsensical statblobs. If Mega Metgross still want its' 145 attack, 105 special attack, and 110 speed, it'll have to eat into it's HP, Defense, and Special Defense to do so even with the points afforded to it, whereas Megas like Audino and Sableye won't have to suffer. This also further pushes the "Megas as an alternative rather than straight updgrade" angle Kalosfags desperately want you to believe applied for more than a small handful of them.
>Z-Moves
When a Pokemon holding a Z-Crystal swaps in, the type of cystal it's holding is announced. For example, you swap Heatran holding a Grassium-Z in and the text "Heatran is a giving off an intensely verdant aura!" shows with an accompanying visual.
>Dynamax
Max HP bonus goes from 2x to 1.5x, ALL stat boosting Max Moves are capped to 100 BP in the BEST case, and Gmaxes are now given the option to use their Gmax moves alongside normal Max Moves. After they Gmax, another prompt like the initial DMax one shows up with a new symbol. Selecting it will allow you to hen use the Gmax move for the corresponding type of move that turn However, you can only do this ONCE. This change is gonna require a mass rebalancing of G-Max moves overall (the Kanto trio's moves literally only need to be used once to get max value in their current state, so cut their duration down to 4 turns, for example), but I think it'd be overall healthier.
Thoughts?

I was sitting and thinking about what kind of dragon you could bring to a trick room team since most dragons are just so fast and it kind of struck me.
How would a min-speed Haxorus work? Lets you put a bunch of stats into it's bulk/defenses instead of speed, will always underspeed Hydreigon because of it's natural 1 lower speed than Hydreigon and if you then also slap Brave on it with 0IV speed leaves you at 91 speed - which sure, is still fast for trick room but if you're facing a non-trick room team, you're most likely going to underspeed all of them. I guess you could also just bring a min-speed, Brave Dragonite since that technically underspeeds as well but it's so common. I like the idea of using Haxorus because Life Orb 252+ Haxorus using First Impression on Hydreigon is always a guaranteed kill unless they're very, very bulky or they tera. Haxorus's natural absolutely monstroud attack would also work well with stuff like a Bronzong so that it can levitate and you have ground coverage without only the use of Earth Power on like, Torkoal.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53089024
The probpem isn't being just too easy or hard. It's the game itself being inconsistent. For the first ~4 gyms, it works out pretty evenly, maybe easy if you don't have a full team, but then after Morty the levels drop out from under you, and depending on what you did early the result in gyms 5-7 is different:
> 1. Only had one/a few pokemon:
your team is probably at a higher level, you don't gain levels very much anymore, but you're already strong enough to quickly sweep through
> 2. already had 6:
Your team is even more likely to stop gaining experience ,but you also are about at the npc levels, so it's just low power STAB spam thanks to the weaker movepools unevolved/lower level mons generally have
>3. had a few, adding to the team:
the worst of both worlds, you have a few pokemon that are strong and can sweep, but any new additions will be weak and won't gain levels, so you're stuck with whatever it has when you catch it

Depending on which situation you're in, either you get to Clair and the league at their level and continue without much issue (this would be option 1), or your team is now relatively underleveled and still mot at their full potential, so it's more boring battles or grinding against the routes to get those last evos/moves (this is usually options 2 and 3)

And then no matter which one you were this time, you get to Kanto, the gyms are weaker, and it's just a casual walk around the region to destroy everything before being 10-20 levels under Red.

Other regions avoid this inconsistency thanks to the exp all, which does make them easy, but also much more well rounded to allow different playstyles instead of having drasitcally different experiences depending on when you caught your party.

Level curve is simply a way to add some difficulty to the game. Fighting red's team with level 40/level 50 mons is a completely different experience to fighting him with level 80 mons, and maxing out red's levels in other to raise the overall level curve means that less thoughtful players can't simply beat him by overlevelling him. The other reason behind the level curve is to make certain special mons like dragonite and tyranitar harder to get, as you need to actually commit to training their pre evolutions before obtaining them - and that only makes them feel that much special.

The other big misconception about gen 1 and gen 2 is that they are all about pokemon battling and thus they are bad because they are not filled with competitive pokemon with optimized move sets, because they and monster COLLECTING games where the real challenge is meeting and capturing as many pokemon as possible, not PvP battling. Gen 2 was the last gen where legendaries were actually elusive rather than handed to you by the plot, even suicune in crystal can be entirely missed if you don't want to follow him - and despite adding the battle tower as a true test for competitive pvp movesets, the real final challenge in that game isn't battling red, it's capturing the three legendary beasts just so you have a chance at battling and capturing ho oh.

posts.com:
Not gonna spam (you)s, you guys know who this is for.

Personally, I’ve never had an issue using more than 6 mons in GSC. But I wanna emphasize: that is 100% because I don’t consider grinding an issue.
People don’t see it this way these days but back then, spending ~hour each day leveling your mons in a nearby area, while engaging in side activities like the game corner, berry collecting, trainer rematches, bug catching contests etc in the downtime to break up the monotony, all that stuff, that WAS the content. That WAS the gameplay. Maybe one day you’d get lucky and run into a rare encounter on your way through an area, maybe you’d get a call about a swarm, maybe you finally win the bug catching contest, etc etc, each day brings with it potential for new experiences, it’s not always about clearing all of what technically counts as “content” in a given area ASAP and then moving on, you MAKE the content by creating your own story using the tools the game gives you. For me that means catching and training like 10-15 mons as I progress, and fully embracing the slower, routine based playstyle that asks of me. For others? Maybe they don’t really want to - and that’s ok. Those players can use proportionally less Pokémon, thus allowing them to progress through the game in a suitably swifter manor.
BUT
When people constantly whine about aspects of the game that aid my playstyle, getting in the way of theirs? Yea, I’m sorry, but it just sounds like you’re playing the game wrong, or more specifically, it sounds like you’re going into the game expecting it to give you an experience it’s not designed to, and then get mad when it doesn’t. You’re not “objectively wrong” or some shit, those issues you’re complaining about “exist”, sure, I wont be disingenuous with you there, but whether or not they’re “issues” at all is a matter of perspective, it may hinder your experience but it bolsters mine

GSC isn't supposed to be super hard

>game opens up
>you can choose which gyms to fight
>you can choose to beat team rocket first
>lots of areas to explore and pokemon to find
It makes grinding up to your opponents' levels for the hard battles a bit tedious, but you REALLY don't need to do that.
You should be able to win against the gyms and elite four with a solid 5-10 level disadvantage compared to the last ace pokemon, if you know what you're doing.
I won't argue that the game design is perfect. It makes some trainers really boring to fight and some really a lot harder, but I think its enjoyable as an overall experience

Based GSC enjoyer. The games really aren’t that difficult, but as with every pokemon game, the player has a lot of control over the difficulty of the experience. The number of times I’ve seen / heard of people doing long grinds for Red is proof enough that some players simply don’t “get” GSC, meaning they aren’t familiar enough with the mechanics to know that Red (and other trainers) are manageable even when massively underleveled.

I will also say that HGSS, good as it is, exacerbates some of the issues people have with GSC, and I think that has made the opinion of Gen 2 more negative with some people, even if they haven’t played the original games. HGSS really would have benefited from making more changes to Johto and rebalancing the Kanto / Johto mon for the attack split. When it comes to rebalancing abilities and stats, I’m not sure why Game Freak is so hesitant. They’ve fucked up several lines over the years with the special stat split and attack split, and a lot of early abilities suck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53103619
>and why do you feel this way
Because the leveling system in Pokemon isn't as simple as just the numbers. When almost all of your team's progression is tied to levels, that 5-10 level gap means way more at 30 than it does at 60, and either you're destroying the NPCs with something that has reached its full potential against random NFEs, or using underpowered mons in long repetitive battles because you don't have any other options, especially in older games when most movepools are 90% weak non-STAB moves and the most useless status options.
A level 50 pokemon fighting a level 60 is a pretty even battle, a level 20 fighting a level 30 is usually very one-sided. The latter hapoens more often in Johto than basically any other region, and it makes the second half of the game feel like you're making barely any progress no matter how many battles you win
>the game doesn't tell you how many to train
They teach you how to catch pokemon, give you a bunch of pokeballs, tell you where to get more pokeballs, and then show you the PC where you can swap around your pokemon to decide which 6 will be in your team. The clear implication is that you will be catching pokemon all throughout your journey, and could use different ones at different times. This is also supported by the early-gen idea of pokemon like bug types being useful early and then replaced once stronger options are available.
Even if you only ever catch 6 pokemon, the odds of them all being in the first few routes is low, and only falls if you play the game multiple times, which makes the difference even more noticable if you catch something and it's 10 levels weaker than the rest of your team, on par with the routes, but nealry useless in the gyms.

You’re walking in the woods with your rucksack. You aren’t the most experienced with packing your ruck, so it’s always so big on you. It’s 11 in the morning, beams of sunlight piercing the rooftop of the forest in small patches, here and there. After a bit of walking, you fight through foliage to see a girl sitting on a boulder. She’s wearing a black dress, has short black hair with a cowlick in the back, in her hair is a white bow. She notices you and greets herself. “I’m Marley. What brings you out here?” You can tell she’s kind of reserved and shy. You inform her that you’re just on a walk. “Really? You must know the way out of this forest. Can I join you?” You tell her “Yes” after a moment of contemplating. It seems kind of suspicious traveling with a girl who looks like she’s still in high school, but her companionship wouldn’t be too bad, especially since you often get lonely in your strolls. Time passes by, and she seems to have warmed up to you after some casual chitchat. “If I’m gonna be honest Anon, I don’t like talking. I can’t figure out what to say to people fast enough, so they just look at me with disgust and confusion. But I can talk to you normally, because you seem to understand me.” As you look at Marley, she looks away, blushing with a cute smile. She has feelings for you, but she’s far too nervous to let them known. After some walking, you both decide to sit under a tree to eat. You pull out goods from your rucksack, getting a can of beefaroni for yourself and giving a PBJ sandwich to Marley. After eating, you pack the trash away in your ruck. Marley is slightly appalled by your inability to effectively pack it tight. “Make it smaller Anon.” She lets out a small but cute chuckle as you begin to wrap around your ruck in a fetal position, humping it in a desperate yet pathetic attempt to make it smaller.

Looking at the constant stream of journeyfics being posted on FFN got me thinking: is it rare for people to do a journeyfic in their homebrew region? It seems a lot more rare than I thought.

I've always had the idea for a journeyfic (as a Pokemon writer, who hasn't?), but I never really seemed to into the idea of using a canon region. Canon characters (gym leaders), yes. I this common with other Pokemon writers?

posts.name: cge0361
posts.com:
>>53105573
I've gone somewhat the other way around.

Although the very first pokemon fic idea I had was in Johto by default, as I was playing HGSS at the time, once I decided to write it out and that some of my pokemon could talk (necessitating a conceit to sell it) I recast it as a homebrew region. It remains somewhat Johto like in broad strokes, and I pulled a bit of a stunt to keep them connected (that there is another archaeological site there claiming to also be the Ruins of Alph, implying a connection which I've left lying there for a decade…), but quickly became its own thing and gave me a lot of blank canvas to work with.

But now I've somewhat returned to it with my current WIP, which follows a canon-region trainer who is going to visit said Ruins, have an experience, and wind up on her way to my region.

As for why, I think that likely most writers want to self-insert and it's much easier to work in the Pokemon World by using places that are there. A homebrew region requires drawing a map to keep it straight.

>Canon characters (gym leaders), yes.
Those would be somewhat bound to canon regions, unless a bunch are visiting the homebrew land for… a convention I guess? See, it takes some doing.

I'm sorry anon I'm fucking retarded. I meant the latter. If the subject is a location name which is rendered in plural, it should be treated as such grammatically. For instance, you'd say
>the weather in the Bahamas is great this time of year

>the Bahamas are wonderful this time of year

posts.name: cge0361
posts.com:
>>53114015
Use what sounds best, foremost. But, if the Mirelands are a bunch of locations, prefer the plural. If it's really one spot, prefer the singular.

In my experience, collective plurals are different in US and UK English, with US favoring the collective as a unit versus UK favouring the collective as a collection. I.e., "Our team is leading in sales," in the US, versus "Our team are leading in sales" in UK. Works on bands and soccer clubs.

Yeah, you absolutely don’t need to do porn, but you need to be hitting some sort of niche/fandom. On RoyalRoad the biggest cash cows seem to be LitRPGs. Levels, stats, the whole enchilada. Doesn’t have to be isekai, but it helps. It’s not really fanfiction and the market’s somewhat saturated, but RR isn’t really a fanfic site to begin with, and hey, it’s what the people demand. I see a lot of authors setting up Patreons and giving of advanced chapters as rewards, so maybe that’d work for you.

On AO3/Wattpad/everything else the big thing seems to be fandoms. Make a really popular story about a popular anime/video game and link your Ko Fi or whatever. At least a couple people will bite, but really it depends on your popularity levels.

On the whole, there’s definitely money to be made. People are a lot more eager to spend money online than they were not that long ago, and it’s baffling to me. Instead of saving up to go to Barnes and Noble and buy a couple books, Zoomers today are probably timing Patreon payments and setting apart commission money to give to internet people.

I finished reading the porygon story. It's the most original fan fiction I have read yet. And among other fanfics I dare to say it's the deepest.

The way you write what goes on the the mind of a porygon is so ingenious, I really felt I was seeing the world through its eyes.

My only critic is that the summary reveals too much about the story. I think I would have been amazed by the progressive reveal of the porygon's condition if I didn't have such a massive hint!

Other than that. Wow. Really loved it. In my opiniom it rivals Diaphanous Perception (Mienshao story). Obviously they can't be compared because of their length but if anyone wants a good short read, go read this porygon story : https://archiveofourown.org/works/18259673

Please write more.

posts.name: cge0361
posts.com:
>>53117071
Regarding the blurb, so short a piece it's difficult to describe it in any other way, and since there is no plot arc, conflict, or even clear motivation in the text, I decided to try putting the reader in the POV of the author of a particular cron job, letting the reader see the fruit of that labor which said author knew would never get to see. Hopefully that's not too meta for an already heavily meta piece.

And besides, one of my principles is that if a story has merit, it's a better read the second time through, so I don't fear minor spoilers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The Legends battle system was perfect. The camera movement and character animations was smooth and to the point, it didn't hang for a few seconds like in SV. The menus felt snappy and responsive unlike SV, and I loved how menu options were assigned to buttons. It's a crime that they went back to the fucking GameBoy menu in SV. The move animations were actually pretty good, and for the first time in the mainline games the Pokémon actually move around and make physical contact. I loved how time sometimes slowed down on the impact when you made super-effective hits and the camera shook a bit, it made battles feel a bit more action-packed. The battles in SV are fucking boring and look like shit. I also hate how zoomed in the battle camera is in SV.

There's also other stuff that Legends did that makes it so great, but I'm not gonna go into any of that. I'll just end it saying PLA was miles better than SV and anyone saying otherwise is a shill or a mindless NPC who doesn't want Pokémon to improve.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53108786
I think this game was just alright, a lot of promise a lot of ass, a lot of soul a lot of slog. I think anyone who finds it the best or worst game is most likely lying to themself out of autistic passion, but ultimately it falls on the better half of the series. I think its mechanical contributions are pretty great, but that its new pokedex and characters are ugly and kinda suck, and while the former criteria will get me to finish a game, the latter criteria really kills its chances of being top tier for me. I can’t say “Oh yeah it’s a perfect take on Pokemon, but all of the new Pokemon are unsightly hideous and the characters are boring fugly fan service” idk about y’all but a game can’t be one of the best with that holding it back. I didn’t mind the crafting or the tasks nearly as much as the autists on this board led me to believe I would, but even then a Pokemon game where the new Pokemon and Pokemon Trainers suck is not a Pokemon game that can ever be higher than middle of the road, I’m sorry bros.

Happy birthday Legends Arceus, you’re not the perfect game, but you were the most fun GF has given us in years, they failed you in terms of your new content and post-launch support, you deserved better. To honor its successes, I shall post one of the three good new Pokemon it gave us.

Comparing SV's plot with SwSh's plot is almost a bit insulting desu. SwSh was obviously rushed to no fucking end, the plot didn't even make any fucking sense because it was obviously half-finished. Rose is a non-character because nothing he does makes sense. Everything it tries to do falls completely flat. I did not give a single shit about the dog legendaries or Eternatus, no matter how much the game tried to make them seem "cool" or whatever.
SV's plot is a bit convoluted, but it seems well thought out and feels pretty done (DLC bait aside of course). To me it seems like they worked on the ending way earlier in the development cycle so they could actually flesh out the things they wanted to do without having to rush it during crunch time. Area Zero clearly had a lot of thought put into its presentation. They put way more care into character writing and giving Arven, Nemona and Penny actual personalities that interact in interesting ways. The box legendary is with us the whole game, you form an actual bond with it and it has some genuinely cool moments that I enjoyed.
But yeah, Turo/Sada do feel a little weird. I'm hoping it's just DLC bait but we'll see.

posts.com: I'm excited and nervous about starting Emerald after finishing Crystal. Do you guys particularly concerned with Natures/Abilities/EVs or do you just roll with the punches?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53027277
Depends on the encounter and game state, some pokemon become liabilities with a bad nature, IVs, and movepool; like -SpA Ralts with poor SpA IVs. While fine as a Gardevoir later on due to the huge Base Stat it won't be strong enough to get there as a normal party member considering it's after the fourth badge. Then at the point where you could level it up to use it, you'll have access to other pokemon, hopefully ones with better stat distributions.

Some notable ones with the issue are
>Treecko
The worst starter in terms of early-mid game
>Poochyena
Without a decent Atk/SpA, won't do enough damage until you it before Wattson. Has Howl but is way too frail to use it. Mightyena has some utility however.
>Beautifly
Too weak and limited in moves to handle poor offensive stats
>Lombre and Nuzleaf
They need stats to balance out their awful movepools
>Ralts
As stated above

Then there's the inverse
>Mudkip and Torchic
Decent moves, coverage, and resistances balance out poor stats
>Zigzagoon
Has pick Up and gets early Headbutt which is a STAB 70 power move with a flinch chance, that with Sand-Attack, Tail Whip and Growl gives a way to set up for other pokemon
>Taillow and Wingull
Access to early Wing Attack and Water gun, respectively, are extremely useful and strong.
>Dustox
It doesn't rely on its stats as it's focused on status and support

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This one cut a little closer than it should have, but 10th game in the challenge is done

Lorelei and Bruno were dealt with Calm Mind sweeps from Slowbro, then instead of risking it through the status effects that Agatha tried to put me through, I pulled out Substitute Raticate. Deny status effects then sweep with Shadow Ball

Things didn't go as planned vs Lance, though. Blogpost incoming
>lead Butterfree to sleep Gyarados so Slowbro can setup
>Gyarados immediately wakes up
>to kill Gyarados and the incoming Dragonair but now Slowbro is at 1/3
>swap to Nidoking
>ice beam city
>freezes Dragonite
>promptly thaws and kills Nidoking with a crit Outrage
Ninetales dealt the final blow but that sucked, now I'm missing a lot of coverage and bulk vs Rival

>lead Raticate vs Pidgeot
>TWave then set up sub on Sand Attack
>kill with Return
>kill Alakazam with Shadow Ball
>Exeggutor comes in and TWave'd
>switch Slowbro and Calm Mind twice
>Ice Beam the eggs
>Gyarados comes in
>crits Bite twice
>leaves me at 20 HP
>in a panic, misplay and switch out, should have just sacrificed him for a free switch
>send out Butterfree
>Toxic then Protect/Psychic until we're both in the red
>predict his Full Restore and put him to sleep in the same turn (felt really good about this one)
>swap into Raticate and set up another sub, then kill with Return
>Charizard comes out and Fire Blasts the sub away
>swap into Ninetales and absorb his next Fire Blast with Flash Fire
>for some reason it Fire Blasts again while I confuse and slowly chip it with HP Electric
>Rhydon comes in
>can't safely switch into anything since Rock Tomb or EQ will kill
>confuse and burn before going down
>send out Raticate
>sub for safety and kill with Return

I had plenty of misplays (including not bringing a 6th to E4) but some of my predictions left me feeling really good, and I can't feel too bad by going all the way with Raticate and Butterfree lol. Rest easy, Mr. Nido and Azsakano.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Clair time, after an excessively long and pointless Rocket and grinding session.
Plan? Lead Parasect, Spore Gyarados and sucks him dry I guess.
Clair decides to do the unthinkable for a Pokemon AI, and switches to Dragonair. I figure this is the fire-breathing one, which is why I led with Parasect to begin with, switching to Magcargo, getting the KO with two AncientPowers.
Kingdra next, I try to switch back to Parasect in hopes of more Sleep spreading, but take too much damage from Not Hydro Pump.
No problem, Miltank can stall as long as is needed and eventually win.
Gyarados comes back in, I switch to Sudowoodo, get a Rock Slide miss after which Gyarados waves up and deals notable damage before falling to a more successful Rock Slide.
Second Dragonair comes out, at which point I go to Girafarig, failing to get the kill due to Paralysis before going back to Mommy Milkers for a lossless win.

Did not go ideally, but good enough.

E4.

Venomoth is handled by Magcargo with no real risk, and Muk + Crobat failed to Double Team vs. Mamoswine. Kind of sweaty, as usual, but just get lucky ok?
>Bruno
Leading with Parasect for Spore, then switching to Girafarig and NOT Baton Passing fast legs to the mushroom was a mistake, as Girafarig is unable to one-shot the musclemen. After therefore losing both Girafarig and Parasect to this critical error, being the only two Pokemon that can deal with Fighting-types, Miltank takes down the rest of the crew, notably the Hitmonchan who can't get through Sub Milk.
>Karen
Speaking of things that can't beat a submissive cow, all of Karen's team. Miltank systematically proceeded to take apart her entire team before Murkrow, as her last Pokemon, Whirlwinded into a giant mammoth that vomits ice on birds.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53072163
>Lance
I had a plan for this involving Agility Passing for the Mamoswine sweep, unfortunately that was no longer an option.
So before the battle, I give Miltank Thunderbolt, and Mamoswine Ice Beam.
Miltank leads, and it turns out, Gyarados struggles with SubMilk too, eventually falling to weather phenomena caused by a cow. Something about Greek mythology goes here.
Unfortunately, this is where it all goes downhill. I need to get Mamoswine in safely, but Miltank can't tank the strongest of the Dragonites indefinitely. Eventually I'm forced to switch in hopes of Outrage hitting in confusion, going to Sudowoodo instead, as probably the most expendable of the team.
He's able to Rock Slide the Dragonite, leading to the second one to come in. I'm not sure which one it is, so I stay in. Turns out it went for Thunder, which would've been a safe switch for Mamoswine. RIP Sudowoodo, your sacrifice won't be forgotten.
Mamoswine puts the DNite to ice, leading to Charizard.
I chose to believe Ancient Power would KO. I was wrong. Should've switched to Magcargo. Two hits was still enough, but Mamoswine is at critical health.
And Lance elects to throw out Dragonite instead of Aerodactyl.
So Lance is down to just Aerodactyl now. I switch to Magcargo here, not wanting to lose Mamoswine, and then go for Yawn. Magcargo lives at critical health, and it's clear that a sack is needed. In the end, while it's certainly the wrong choice in terms of future success, it's time for the milk factory to close down. RIP Miltank, what an absolute unit.
After this, Mamoswine comes in to clean house with Ice Beam + Ice Shard.

Mistakes were definitely made here. Mostly that I lost a lot of utility because of the fight vs. Bruno. I probably could've also shaved losing Miltank vs. Lance. That said, we're still living. I'm not sure how to rebuild from here, but I have some options.

Crystal is done! Here's the breakdown of the final battle:
>Baku puts Pikachu to sleep. Red wastes a Full Restore to wake him up (while at full HP no less) before a Psychic takes him out in one hit.
>Espeon is next, Dagda makes easy work of him with a Mean Look + Toxic combo, along with Feint Attacks powered up with STAB + Black Glasses to speed up the process.
>For Snorlax, I had Dagda set up Mean Look + Toxic again before switching to Apis. A fully-powered Return with a held Pink Bow helps make this as painless as possible for me.
>Venusaur's turn; Kaso criticals a Flamethrower before he can do anything of note.
>Mazu is sent out against Blastoise, a Rain Dance-boosted Thunder is an OHKO.
>CHARIZARD is a chump thanks to Inanna's Surf (and a Mystic Water).
On to Emerald!

>>53116912
Honestly don't know why so many people seem to have that mindset, that they need the community's approval to do things. Like we're going to banish them if they deviate from what we like.
Like, hell, you can just decide that a death didn't count if you want to. Will we think that defeats the spirit of the run? Sure, but it's your run dude, you do what you wanna do.
One time I wiped at the champion in a run of Sun, and I normally do "wiping is a game over" but this time since I was at the final battle, I decided to keep 1 member and re-train a new team around it and tried again and won.
Nuzlocke is all about making the playthrough more interesting than it normally would be. It's not about rigid unflinching rules.

Yeah, I have a hax clause for Evasion spam since there's nothing you can do about it and it reduces the rates to 33% at +6. There's a reason why the preferred strat for it is to PP stall it with mons you sack.

Something like pokemon chronicles were it's a bunch of stories about people aside from the MC but instead it takes place in game canon. There can be mini arcs that are spread out between multiple episodes and air unsequentially like a series of 3 episodes that focus on a team rocket grunt. 1st one shows them joining TR and everything they did until red disbanded them. 2nd one shows their life post TR and their eventual return to the group after 2 years in Johto. 3rd episode is them in unova reflecting over everything. >>53115271
Of course it should be ongoing-plot, how else would Trainer earn badges? That doesn't mean there wouldn't be episodic episodes.
Trainer goes on a pokemon journey through the mountain lands, trying to uncover (something). Lots of old building, old temples, occasional hermit priests. Lots of old Japanese culture. A good amount of classic samurai movie influences. Trainer finds the treasure pretty quickly, like second episode, because it's been found, it's empty, why would anyone leave treasure just lying there when they could go back and take it. So Trainer has to do things like catalogue the inscriptions in the old temples, fight the pokemon in the way, etc. And then there's the temple kids, who pokemon battle trying to run him off. Tense showdowns in the streets and allyways.
As for not straight-up porn, OK, but the occasional wardrobe near-malfunction, or making fun of some of the humans would be a good idea. Misty mudwrestling magazine, with Misty in her black Team Rocket swimsuit, just a series of photographs taken during a thing that happened and printed in a magazine. This is a mistranslation. Here's what he actually said:
>"I see. Most Pokemon in Gold & Silver were of the cute variety, but this time…”
>Sugimori: "Our priority with Pokemon has always been to create an even split of ‘cute’ and ‘cool’. But at that time, the breeding mechanic was a heavily advertised new feature in Gold & Silver, and so there were many ‘baby’ Pokemon created to showcase this. So even with the many ‘cool’ designs of those games, we felt that the audience would misinterpret this as an imbalance. So for Ruby and Sapphire, we had to make ensure that this notion of imbalance did not reoccur, and we ended up making a lot of cool new designs."
>”When you were designing Pokemon around the time of Gold & Silver, were you now taking merchandising into consideration, and did this ultimately cause any constraints for the new designs?”
>Sugimori: “Rather than constraints, I’d say we were careful about a lot of things. Like we’d say ‘this Pokemon is cuter/stronger, so it should act like this’. However this time we didn’t really dwell on this too much.”
That last quote, he is referring to both Gen 1 and 2 Pokemon with cute/strong in mind. Please stop with the blatent lying.

posts.name: Latias4Life
posts.com:
Good to be back!

First off, I made a Secret Garden themed phone notification sound for people to download and use if they want. I use it on Telegram! :D

Here: https://vocaroo.com/1i18eBQnqfhD

I also finally watched the two episodes of Pokemon: Aim to be a Pokemon Master with near perfect English translations, and I'm so convinced that it's movie 5 Latias!

- Ash recognizes her for SURE! He even asked her what was wrong point blank when all she was doing was seeming hostile toward him, like HE knew the behavior was strange for her.

- What are the odds that they'd decide to introduce an entirely different Latias? Makes little sense.

- I think it's just been too long since she last saw him, and she's been through too much. Also, she got hit pretty hard in the air and was possibly disoriented.

- You can tell Latias has the same affinity for him. I think there was a spark of realization when he got hit by the electricity while trying to rescue her from the icy globe. It was almost a "this is my knight in shining armor" way she saw him for a second.

- When she grabbed and flew with him and they held hands, you could tell she was kind of in shock, like she was experiencing old feelings.

- When she flew away at the end, she didn't revert to a "BAKA!" like tsundere personality. She just floated away with a really confused look in her eyes, like, "I need to process this."

Obviously there had to be some sort of conflict that they need to resolve between them. They can't just have Latias follow him around like a lovesick puppy.

Still kind of in shock that Latias beat Misty to having shippy moments. Ash really tended to Latias and seemed so loving... so heartwarming! I had a near perfect translation for episode 2 and Misty was obsessed with that clauncher, practically calling it her soulmate. Latias definitely has a better chance! Can't wait to see where this goes! :D

posts.name: Latias4Life
posts.com:
Gonna practice writing a couple small slices of life in case I want to finish my fic.

Pokemon Master ~ Day 27

Silvery moonlight cascaded down through the canopy of trees that sprawled in abundance throughout the Secret Garden. A June breeze caused branches and leaves to sway, creating scintillating moving patterns over a certain eon's minuscule and reflectively white feathers.

The humid, subtropical climate of Altomare was proving unusually cool this time of year with warm, moist air dominating, but occasional chilly gusts coming from a competing storm front to the north.

One such gust caused a certain human Pokemon master to shiver and whine in his sleep. Latias gazed at Ash with her golden eyes, taking in the details of his prone form, such as the way his skin scrunched up and formed little pimples, and how his dark, spiky coal black hair fluttered against his exposed forehead. He was fully covered the way humans seemed to prefer to be in public, but Latias wondered and fretted over if it was enough.

He looked so soft and vulnerable to the psychic and dragon type, his body far less powerful and resilient than her own. However, it was the strength of his heart and determination of his mind that caused Latias' heart to latch on to him, deciding to share with him any physical advantages she could.

"Laaaa," she whispered to her love as softly as she could before gently sliding a claw beneath his side and draping the other over him. In this embrace, she pulled him close to her soft, warm jetlike body, all exposed human skin becoming immersed in her down. The effort caused the large hammock they were sharing to swing back and forth, creating further friction against their spooning bodies.

When Ash's shivering stopped, the eon cooed and nestled her neck into the crook of his and closed her eyes. She still wasn't sure what their future held, but for now, having him near was enough. The sound of his heartbeat soon lulled her into a secure slumber.

Man, this is so much to wrap my head around.

So the fact that the original VA didn't reprise her role as Latias might be a hint it's a different Latias. However, she might be too old to replicate the sound. Then again, they should be able to use stock sounds from the 5th movie. Buuuut, those might be proprietary to a distributor and they can't. There's also precedent that they've done it before in such a situation? Too much!

Maybe they just figured Latias' voice in the 5th movie was a bit too jarring and wanted to dial it back and the original VA couldn't accomplish it, and of course they couldn't use the old sounds cuz they wanted something new.

I remember too someone suggesting this Latias, if new, seems younger. Maybe she's actually just older. More mature . Doesn't need to vocalize or dart around like a juvenile like she used to. Maybe they wanted a new voice to reflect that. A lot can change when you've had to grow up quickly and you lose people you love. I still think she's processing her feelings and realizing she likes him again... or there's always the amnesia theory and she's falling in love all over again, wondering why it feels so familiar.

Gods, I don't know. I'm not giving up on team original Latias just yet. I feel like if she does confront him again, there's a 90% chance they'll acknowledge their past somehow. I can't see them bringing Latias back now that she's seemingly interested in him and leaving it completely ambivalent. I would hate the idea that some new Latias just opportunistically slides into the original Latias' role. We KNOW that Ash acted differently to her presence than he should have if she was brand new. He's going to want answers or it'll look weird!

They've got the Pokeshippers panicking because Misty is showing no interest in Ash, and they have us playing "Whose frickin' Latias is this?" Pokemon really likes playing with the shippers!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'm definitely clinging to the far-fetched amnesia theory. Even though Latias getting angry and trying to rip off the bandages looks really bad, she didn't show a whole new personality like some have said afterward, i.e. tsundere Latias.

She was just distrustful at first, and then seemed to be confused, but now that she's following Ash, she's acting more like the first one. I feel like a lot of her expressions after she witnessed him protect her and then flew with him and eventually floated away, seems like she was processing either confused old feelings, or brand new feelings since it could be a different Latias, but not necessarily one with a wildly different personality. Hopefully the show is going somewhere with this narratively and we'll have a definitive answer by the end.

But I think we should at least give it to their final confrontation before we devise a new shipping name for the new Latias. If by the end they don't provide a bombshell, I'm willing to concede that it's a new Latias.

If anyone else still kind of feels like there's a minute chance it's the old Latias, rest assured you're not alone. :)

timeline for korea doesnt add up
keep in mind, gen 1 pokemon was supposed to be based in the real world, it was only later that they changed it to be in an alternate universe
so if it was supposed to be set in the real world in 1995, korea happened way too far back, surge would be way older in 1995
vietnam adds up, age wise
if he was an ordinary conscripted soldier (theres no reason to believe he was a higher, career soldier, because then he would have had a cushy safe job and wouldnt have been in such a hairy situation that he needed electric pokemon to save his ass, thats a grunt's job), he would have been born anywhere from 1944 to 1950
callups in subsequent years (1971 to 1975) adjusted for men born later, anywhere up to born in 1956
so lets say born anywhere from 1944-56
so in 1975 he could have been aged 19-31
so in 1995 he'd be 39-51
perfectly plausible given his appearance in the games and anime

>>53093291
Not only my favorite gen 2 memory but Pokémon overall.
>be eh 7 or 8
>few years after game came out
>get gameboy and crystal version for Christmas
>keeps me distracted from chaos at home
>play with my friends who come from wealthy family at after school daycare
>on my way to catch the beasts
>misguided fat kid smacks gameboy out of my hands and trips me
>I fall straight down into stomach and knees
>Out of breath and gameboy is totally kill
>regain breath, notice fallen gameboy and run off crying
>go to PE area where no one is and just breakdown in grass
>find a gold necklace with a locket in grass
>open locket and see fancy pic of a girl I know and some man
>wipe tears away and go to find her
>find her in cafeteria
>give her necklace and she kisses me on the cheek and thanks me at least 10 times
>turns her back on me as she shows her friends she found it and I go back to empty PE area
>lay down on grass and see a cloud shaped like a big pretty bird
>makes me smile
>hear running sounds and “hey anon!” From hallway
>it’s cool rich friend and his sister
>gives me my crystal version cart
>mentions how he has 2 gameboy advances for trading and I can have one
>in disbelief so I hug him tight
>sister hugs both of us
>look back at bird cloud
>go back to cafeteria to get Hawaiian Punch and goldfish and we catch the beasts and ho-oh together
I will NEVER forget you Dallas. We were both pure of heart.

posts.com: I don't want Unova remakes, I want a Unova reimagining. Given SV setting a new standard in pokemon world design, it would be pretty jarring to go back to the previous design afterwards. I want Unova to be as a open world as Paldea while keeping the core locations of the region. I want Pinwheel Forest to be this huge, lush forest with no barriers between the outside and inside areas. I want to swim to Castelia City near by the Skyarrow Bridge. I want to climb Twist Mountain from the outside instead of going inside. And so on and so forth. I figure it won't work too well for the first two games given their narratives, but I want it to happen for the possible third game.

You want to get your initial 4 points off at the start of the match, then fight and take the enemy farm and score there for 3 stacks max.
>If they both contest you
Expect death but try to escape, you may not even get that first goal in.
>If one contests you
You can contest one mob but you'll peter out and have to go back to goal or risk death
>If theres a Sableye
You're probably getting mugged and not even getting that first stack.

If your lane goes poorly then you can try stacking later in the game. Its fine to play selfishly for stacks and ignore a Regi.

>>53115543
Power creep, many Pokemon are not as effective as they USED to be. Talonflame used to be an amazing jungler and one of the best backcappers. Now, he's just dies in most fights and you can do the backcapping job ten times easier and better if you're a Sableye or Dodrio.

Monetization creep and more paywalling. They used to do a lot of events for new mons to give you a chance at getting them. In the early seasons, you could reasonably play the game for months without spending a dime and still acquire a lot of licenses. Now, everything is locked behind a $20 - $40 wall with no event to unlocked them. I think Sableye was the only recent mon you were able to get for free? Before that, it went as far back as Mew. Maybe someone can correct me if I'm wrong.

Remoat is gone and Theia is the new map. The farm placement is better, the objectives are bit more balanced in terms of desire (Even though people still say go bottom, you won't be at a gigantic disadvantage if your team all goes top compared to Drednaw). Rayquaza used to be good, but they changed how his buff works and lowered hi HP so he basically feels like Zap again where he is THE deciding factor and "the first 8 minutes don't matter".

Rated in regards to ambition, skill, knowledge, and power of the Pokemon they possess:

Iris >>> Misty > Brock > Clemont > Cilan > Dawn > Serena > May > Lillie

Iris is the clear winner because she's been shown to have powerful pokemon, is a regional champion, and is an expert on dragon pokemon. Misty is above Brock because she's more dedicated to battling specifically and determined to be the best, plus she's got some heavy hitters behind her. Brock's above Clemont and Cilan because the pokemon we've seen him use are stronger than anything they have, and his knowledge of pokemon as a breeder/physician is probably the highest of everyone listed. Dawn, Serena, and May aren't weak battlers but battling isn't their main focus and their pokemon are trained to perform more than fight. Lillie probably has the least fighting experience of anyone listed period.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53113708
The game is more or less a 1:1 remake of Diamond and Pearl with very little acknowledgement of Platinum. There's a "Distortion Room" that lets you catch some legendaries, and there's the grand underground which once you beat the game allows you to catch every Pokemon from 1 to 493 barring of course the distortion room's legendary's the main game's legendaries, and mythicals. However starters, pseudos, and everything in between are all on the table which is kinda neat, I must admit. However, the secret bases have been drastically oversimplified, with the only decorations now being statues you can place to affect spawns in the underground. Think Scarlet and Violet's type encounter boosting sandwiches, except these aren't on a timer. The game uses Sword and Shield's forced exp share and bundles the affection and friendship stats into one so all the bonuses you'd get from playing Amie, Refresh, or Camp in prior games like the extra chance to dodge or crit, surviving otherwise fatal attacks at 1HP, and curing itself of statuses are obtained the same way friendship is meaning you're stuck with them further trivializing the already easy game unless you go out of your way to only use herbal medicines that lower friendship to heal up after battle, and even then you have to wait until Celestic Town to even do that. The only other changes I can think of are Cynthia having a pretty strong team for modern Pokemon's standards and the contests being even further simplified into a rhythm minigame. Other than all that though it's the same Diamond and Pearl you played 15 years ago, for better and for worse as they made no attempt to remedy any of the original DP's more glaring flaws. Tl;dr, Platinum's better.

posts.com: Professional author anon here, been thinking about starting a PMD story. What are some Do’s and Don’ts? What would you like and not like to see in a PMD fic?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53092254
There aren't really any set in stone tips. There are stories I've read that follow the usual story beats of "human wakes up a Pokemon, has amnesia, has to save the world with their new friends" and they're enjoyable. There are edgy as fuck stories that up the ante with heavier themes and violence, and with the right approach they can work. It's all dependent on the author and their style. Can you make a story and the world it occurs in believable? Can the characters be cared for by the audience? If you can achieve that, you're golden.

I will say though, my favorites are when people take the formula and run with just the basics. Talking Pokemon with their own society, teams that fulfill jobs and handle issues, some kind of overarching threat/plot, and enough to tie it all together nicely. Don't even have to involve humans or anything of the sort.

LGP/E, Sw/Sh, BD/SP, PLA, S/V, Mystery Dungeon DX, Pokken DX, New Pokemon Snap, Unite

Pokemon GO, Pokemon Bank, Pokemon Home

With all that information, which Eras of Pokemon were the best and worst?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53117845
DS Era was easily the best, no question. GBA is the only other one that even comes close. DS Era not only had arguably the best mainline games with Platinum, HGSS, and BW/BW2, but also still had a large abundance of experimental new spinoff titles and improved updated entries of spinoff series introduced on the GB and GBA.
From 3DS onward not only do we start seeing fewer new spinoff ideas, but the existing spinoff series see some of their worst entries and many of them die with the 3DS.
The Switch is definitely the worst. Most spinoff series are dead, and those that survive are only with ports of old titles, not even new releases. Mobage has risen in popularity, the paid online storage model introduced with Bank on the 3DS doesn't even work with new games on release or ever in the case of mons that have been dexcut, the mainline games are getting worse and worse, and even the remakes of DP are low quality compared to the remakes of old that we saw on the GBA, DS, and 3DS.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53115093
In Scarlet you run out of things to do quickly. There's nothing for a post game once you finish Area Zero besides a handful of 5* raids to unlock 6-7*. If my gf wasn't a shitter who can't do raids I'd have turned my copy in a few days after purchase. Instead I solo the raids then trade or breed the raidmon for her.

Snap is at least fun in that there's different routes to unlock, different paths for day/night, and you need to replay courses to get different pokemon. The judging criteria is very different from the original Snap- some pics that would have been perfect on n64 were only 1-2* and others that would have been shit on n64 were 3-4*. Plus the pokemon in the overworld actually have character. I'd like to see Bamco do a mainline Pokemon entry- they have experience through the Digimon World/Story series and programming competence to make decent animations for every single pokemon without sacrificing other areas like floor integrity and feminine women.

Mewtwo is an artificial Pokémon. It is a bipedal, humanoid Pokémon with some feline features. It is primarily gray with a long, purple tail. On top of its head are two short, blunt horns, and it has purple eyes. A tube extends from the back of its skull to the top of its spine, bypassing its neck. It has a defined chest and shoulders, which resemble a breastplate. The three digits on each hand and foot have spherical tips. Its tail is thick at the base but thins before ending in a small bulb.

Mewtwo was created after years of horrific gene splicing and DNA engineering experiments based on Mew. It is widely known as one of the most powerful Pokémon in existence and is said to have the most savage heart among all Pokémon, lacking compassion and striking fear into its enemy with cold, glowing eyes. Because it was engineered to be the ultimate opponent in battle, it can only think of defeating its foes. In the first movie, where it was shown to be capable of levitation, telepathy, mind control, and the ability to create powerful storms, Mewtwo exemplified these vicious characteristics. However, it was later shown to be caring, protective, and even altruistic. Another Mewtwo in the anime shared its aversion to contact with others but was much less belligerent. Mewtwo conserves energy by remaining motionless in order to unleash its full power in battle. Though rarely seen in the wild, it is said to be resting in a dark cave somewhere.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I found my old Pokemon drawings folder from inbetween 2006-2008 when i was i. Elementary school. I have about 20 or so pictures, just felt like sharing my time capsule. Feel free to post any of your childhood Fakemon drawings as well

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I didn't draw many real pokemon, I was always inventing new ones and drawing them. This is probably the earliest drawing and there are some clear influences from Pokemon Red sprites which was the first game I played

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: First "original" designs, very bad haha

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Getting better, lots of gen 1 influence. I still like multiheaded designs, loved Scovillain in the new games

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Two of my favorite recurring designs. Loved Seedot but wanted to see him keep the acron design. Also a rock type oddish basically

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Another version of those two lines. Crazy there still isn't a rock/grass pokemon, the combo seems like a no brainer

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I really liked the Gengar line and I had a fixation with floating hands

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Sorry if some of the pictures aren't clear, the paper is old and faded

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Snompus and Crosist are two designs I still like, kindof like a blend between chinchou and huntail but with Crab claws

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Spore influenced my designs a lot, nothing here really jumps out at me. A lot of my designs shared a similar "circle on blob feet" shape

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Pokedex entries, slight redesigns

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Color on the rest of them. I still really like Vinekorn

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Return of an old design, and a Cold Steel donut steel grim reaper legendary. I guess everyone has their edgy phase

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Epic

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Last one probably, haven't looked at these in a while and I feel this is the only place I'd feel like sharing. I might try and redraw some of these, but I'm probably still not that great at drawing. Thanks for reading

posts.com: Damn guys, I'm happy you guys enjoyed looking at these, its really cool to hear about your childhood fakemons too. Yes, because I would judge how old they are if they're dating minors.

Anyway, based on player characters with actual confirmed ages:
--
>Red: 11 years old (RBYFRLG) (http://www.gamesdatabase.org/Media/SYSTEM/Nintendo_Game_Boy//Manual/formated/Pokemon_-_Blue_Version_-_1998_-_Nintendo.pdf), 14 (GSCHGSS)( Pokémon Gold, Silver, and Crystal take place 3 years after the Generation I core series games ), 28 (B2W2)( Pokémon Black 2 and White 2 take place 17 years after the Generation I core series games), 30 (SMUSUM)(Pokémon Sun, Moon, Ultra Sun, and Ultra Moon take place 19 years after the Generation I core series games)
>Brendan/May: 12 (as rival) (ORAS) (Pokémon Omega Ruby and Alpha Sapphire: Brendan/May, 12, a Pokémon Trainer from Littleroot Town. - Hoenn News Network, emphasis added)
>Hilbert/Hilda: 14 (http://raim2005.blog18.fc2.com/blog-entry-980.html Site is in Japanese))
>Elio/Selene: 11 (SMUSUM) ( Wicke asks if the player and Hau are 11, the minimum age required to take on the Island Challenge, and the player can respond with "Yeah, I am" or "How'd you know?".)
>Rei/Akari: 15 (PLA) (Cyllene: "Hmm. You look to be 15 or so. Quite old enough to work for your keep.")

Yes, I know that Calem/Serena crouch but in the case of Emma, He/She's taller than her. It's also because of the new 3D aspect that the 3DS introduced to the mainline games. If you're wondering why I took this kong to repky, I was using Bulbapedo for research. So yeah, only these specific player character have their ages confirmed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53058241
Yeah, the way it's teeth are placed, along the outside rather than the inside, reminds me of crocodiles, meaning it likely doesn't use them to chew, at least not the things that can actually fit inside of them, unlike steel beams. And since the 'neck' that connects the jaws to Mawile's head is so small, it probably can't swallow anything either. If it did, it'd need to have an esophagus going down through the brain, which just sounds like a disaster waiting to happen.
Which means that Mawile's hind jaws probably act like a venus fly-trap, using secretions to dissolve whatever it holds inside and absorb the nutrients released down through the 'neck'. It would arrive at the brain first, so it'd also be a good biological explanation for why Mawile is smart enough to deceive others.

>>53114475
If you can find a cheap enough SKS they're perfect for beginners in shitty cities/states. They're old semi-automatic combloc rifles so they're borderline invincible, not a lot of parts so learning how they (and guns in general) operate isn't intimidating, they eat any 7.62x39 ammo you find (just make sure you clean it if you're shooting corrosive rounds) so you can get a lot of cheap range time in, and if they're in their original wooden stock they're almost featureless so they're legal basically everywhere.
Only issue is that people discovered this and now they're not $300 bucks anymore
Or if you don't wanna buy anything yet there's guys like ForgottenWeapons on youtube that autism about guns in depth while you wait
